conclusion: Understanding the problem involves identifying the uniform horizontal electric field, the positively charged ball with mass m starting at point O, initial velocity v₀ at angle θ from the opposite direction of E, and the need to find the change in electric potential energy between O and the highest point.
The image shows a uniform horizontal electric field E, a positively charged ball at point O, and initial velocity v₀ at angle θ from the opposite direction of E.

Setting up a coordinate system where the x-axis is horizontal opposite to E and the y-axis is vertical upward, with forces acting on the ball being electric force qE in the negative x-direction and gravitational force mg in the negative y-direction.
Analyzing the motion, the ball moves in a straight line at angle θ, with initial velocity components v₀x = v₀cos(θ) in the x-direction and v₀y = v₀sin(θ) in the y-direction.
At the highest point, the vertical velocity becomes zero, and the time taken to reach the highest point is t = v₀sin(θ)/g.
Calculating the horizontal displacement to reach the highest point as x = (v₀²sin(θ)cos(θ))/g.
Calculating the vertical displacement to the highest point as y = (v₀²sin²(θ))/(2g).
Calculating the change in electric potential energy as ΔU = -qE(v₀²sin(θ)cos(θ))/g.
The difference in electric potential energy when the ball reaches the highest point compared to point O is ΔU = -qE(v₀²sin(θ)cos(θ))/g.
